boardgame.name: G-Core Deluxe
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:
Welcome to G-Core Deluxe!

What is G-Core? G-Core is a simple set of rules for use in any genre. Spawned and updated for the modern gamer, G-Core roots come from the original MarvelTM Superheroes Role-Playing Game or more famously known as FASERIP. This ISN'T the original FASERIP nor is it a product of Marvel Comics, but it is 99% compatible with it.

DELUXE offers even MORE than G-Core!

You get:
LOADS of generics including animals and giant seahorses!
Newer core mechanics to make G-Core even MORE player friendly!
MORE POWERS than EVER!
Best of all it's 71 pages of full color fun!
ALL sorts of bells and whistles!

Worried about real compatibility? We took a character from the old FASERIP game and changed it to G-Core in less than 20 seconds!

Selling Points: -Easy to learn rules -Kid friendly Complete Rules -including: 1d10 mechanics, powers list, game master support -Only needs a ten-sided die -FULL COLOR -Compatible with FASERIP -LOADS of FREE online FASERIP material

boardgame.name: Nexus
boardgame.description:
Nexus (working title) is an abstract strategy game for two players in which you want to be the first to occupy the opponent's home blocks. The playfield is comprised of a series of three-dimensional blocks that can be re-configured to create paths.

To start, the three red and three blue home blocks are placed on opposite sides of the game board with the corresponding pawns on top. Each player rolls a die to determine how many action points (APs) he can spend on his turn; the points can be divided between moving pawns and modifying the board. The possible actions are:


Move (1 AP) — Move a pawn to any orthogonal, unoccupied adjacent face if the path is unbroken. If a player lands on an opposing pawn, that pawn returns to one of its home cubes.



Add Block (1 AP) — Add a purple block to the board adjacent to one of your pawns. This block defines a path that all players must follow. Blocks can be stacked vertically.



Rotate Block (2 AP) — Rotate any unoccupied adjacent block; blocks below other blocks cannot be rotated.



Remove Block (3 AP) — Remove any unoccupied adjacent block from the board; blocks below other blocks may not be removed.


Red and blue home blocks cannot be rotated, removed or stacked upon. The first player to move all three of his pawns to his opponent's home blocks wins.

boardgame.name: Meander
boardgame.description:
Meander is a mechanized board game with a game board that rotates on its own while players try to reach their home base on the opposite side of the board.

To start, each player has five colored spheres in a starting area of the corresponding color. Players take turns moving their spheres one space per turn — but a turn can occur only when the board has paused and isn't currently moving. If a player has a sphere in hand when the board starts to rotate, he must return the sphere to the start position. A player cannot move into a colored space other than his own. If a player moves a sphere to the center of the game board, he can warp that sphere to the home position. Two spheres cannot occupy the same space. The first player to move all of his spheres to his home spaces wins.

For a different gameplay experience, during set-up, each player takes turns placing neutral white spheres on the game board, one sphere per player. The neutral spheres can be moved by any player and serve as blockers.

boardgame.name: Olympian Breed: Setting Primer & Character Creation Guide
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:
Olympian Breed by Palewolf Publishing is a table top roleplaying game set in the Greek heroic age. This game uses the core rules set of the Savage Worlds, Deluxe Edition, the Super Powers Companion (for the God-like powers) and the Fantasy Companion (for the mythical monsters). You need access to all three of these essential resource books in order to create characters and to play in this setting. Fast! Furious! Fun!

With the information contained here and in future releases, you bring your players into an epic tale of high adventure in ancient Greece and beyond. Each release is complete game session with story elements, plot hooks, detailed NPC’s and Game Master tips. The stories can be presented to players as “one shot episodes” or as part of a whole campaign with story threads to tie it all together.

boardgame.name: Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn
boardgame.description:
Square Enix Ltd., the publisher of SQUARE ENIX® interactive entertainment products in Europe and other PAL territories, announced today the fully-redesigned massively multiplayer online adventure FINAL FANTASY® XIV title. Rebranded FINAL FANTASY® XIV: A Realm Reborn™, and previously referenced as “version 2.0,” this adventure has been rebuilt from the ground up, and centers on the core concept of rebirth, featuring a new world to explore and storyline to experience.

FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn offers visually-stunning graphics and game design that appeal to both Windows PC and PlayStation®3 players.
“Since announcing our plans for the future of the title last October, we have been working tirelessly to include all of the elements that we have promised in FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn, which we announced today. This new title not only becomes a symbol of a completely new FINAL FANTASY XIV, but also marks the beginning of a new stage as the latest title in the FINAL FANTASY series. I hope you’re looking forward to it!” said Naoki Yoshida, Producer/Director of FINAL FANTASY XIV.

A new website dedicated to FINAL FANTASY XIV: A Realm Reborn (www.finalfantasyxiv.com) which offers background information on the realm of Eorzea, its inhabitants and the much larger world of Hydaelyn. The website will also serve as the central location for regular updates and news about the game.

Source: The Official Press Release (behind Pay Wall).

boardgame.name: Conan the Barbarian
boardgame.description:
"Conan the Barbarian" is an adventure wargame for 2 to 4 players with each of the players representing one of the major factions of Hyboria. Each faction has agents at their disposal with which they attempt to thwart their enemies plans while enlisting the aid of Conan. There are five types of agents: Wizards, Warriors, Courtesans, Assassins, and Thieves. Each type of agent has different capabilities and different strategies for enlisting the aid of our hero.

SPI's planned "Conan the Barbarian" adventure wargame featured a full-color map of Hyboria and counters for every major character. A pre-publication play test kit was released. There was comprehensive background material written by L. Sprague de Camp.

boardgame.name: Power Play: Schemes & Skulduggery
boardgame.description:
Power Play: Schemes & Skulduggery is a new kind of storytelling game, a "Competitive Narrative Game". In the game, you will take on the role of a supernatural mastermind with a villainous plot to execute. The first to put all the pieces of his secret plot into place can declare himself the winner!

Power Play: Schemes & Skulduggery is not a role-playing game. You will not act out your character's actions, you will not need to adhere to any in-game moral code or class restrictions, and you will not need to keep your out-of-game knowledge separate from your in-game knowledge. On your turns, simply dictate your actions, and they come to pass. Utilize secret actions, your supernatural powers, the resources of your vast agency, and superior planning to gain an advantage and be the first to complete your objective.

Power Play: Schemes & Skulduggery is underhanded, unrestricted supervillainy in a free-form, open environment. We like to think of it as "the Grand Theft Auto of storytelling games".

boardgame.name: Nauticus
boardgame.description:
Harbor life, merchant ships, and boxes full of valuable goods in the heyday of the Hanseatic League – this is the setting for Nauticus from designers Wolfgang Kramer and Michael Kiesling. Each player runs a shipyard and tries to assemble ships of various sizes in order to ship goods with those same vessels. Time is short as each action can be executed only once per round, assembly of the masts and sails must be precisely coordinated, and the goods can be shipped only when the ship is complete. Thanks to the customized action wheels, everyone is always involved in the game's rapid sequence of actions.

Whoever builds the biggest ships and ships the most valuable goods will be the winner in the end.

boardgame.name: Manno Monster
Mnoho monster
boardgame.description:
Manno Monster is a game about monster-parties. Several of such parties have been planned, but only certain monsters have been invited!

There are two times three types of monsters in the game (fat vs thin, red vs blue vs yellow). Each player receives fifteen tiles. Each tile shows a monster on one side, and another monster on the other side (each possible duo of six monster types once). Each round, a card is drawn, that graphically shows which monsters have been invited to the party, such as: "exactly two large red monsters", "at least one small blue monster". In higher difficulty levels the tasks are fuzzier, such as "more yellow monsters than red monsters" or "just as many blue as fat monsters".

After revealing a card with the task description, all players attempt to flip their tiles in real time, so that the invited monsters are shown. The first player that succeeds in doing so collects the most valuable diamond. Other players can still score, too, if they manage to complete the task within the alotted time, started by the first player who (thinks he) fulfilled the task.
After nine rounds, the player who collected best-scored diamonds is declared the winner.

The game comes with six difficulty levels, each level having 18 tasks on the cards.

boardgame.name: Mealtime Sabotage
boardgame.description:
Mealtime Sabotage is a strategic card game where food is your weapon. The goal of the game is to create a complete meal with the fewest calories possible. In addition to the food cards you need to build your meal (entree, 2 sides, dessert and drink), there are sabotage cards which change the value of each food card.

Each player starts the game with 5 cards. On each turn, the active player draws one card and plays one card. Sabotage cards can be played on any place setting, but they cannot stack (one sabotage card per food item). Once your meal is complete, you can play food items on other place settings. The game is finished when all meals are complete. The player with the lowest calorie meal, wins.

boardgame.name: Les Marchaux II: Dupont 1808 Victor 1811 Suchet 1813
boardgame.description:
Les Maréchaux (The Marshals) is an operational wargame designated to simulate campaigns led by French marshals and generals of French Revolution and 1st Empire, when Napoleon was not directly acting on the theater of operations.

The game includes three scenarios:
- "Dupont 1808" related to general Dupont's campaign in south of Spain against spanish general Castaños, during summer 1808.
- "Victor 1811" related to marshal Victor's campaign near Cadix against general La Peña trying to relieve the cit'y siege with help of an english division, late winter 1811.
- "Suchet 1813" related to marshal Suchet's campaign against general Murray for the last big battle in Aragona, spring 1813.

Players are moving divisions and brigades on a "point to point" map. They have to deal with supply, forced march and to prepare battles. The leaders of each army have a key role in coordinating actions.

The game includes:
- one A4 map for Dupont's campaign;
- one A4 map for Victor's campaign;
- one A4 map for Suchet's campaign;
- 108 die-cut counters;
- independent rules and scenarios booklet.

Available with French rules, but English rules can be downloaded from Vae Victis or Designer's website.


The first game in the series is Les Marchaux: Junot 1808 Soult 1809 with two campaigns in Portugal.

boardgame.name: Cubetractor
boardgame.description:
Cubetractor is a neo-retroesque action-strategy-puzzle hybrid where you defeat enemies through an unconventional cube-pulling, turret-building mechanic.

The game carries elements of a reverse tower defense and a grounded bullet-hell dodger to deliver a unique gameplay experience presented in a classic top-down perspective.

You play as Endroi, a menacingly happy-go-lucky quadrubot as he strives to master the art of Cubetracting -- the art of attracting Cubes. It's a deceptively straightforward skill that involves dexterity, acute awareness, multi-tasking and tactical positioning. You'll have to strategize, solve and fight your way through multitudes of enemy installations to achieve your coveted goal.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Deep Down
deep down
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – VAPORWARE




This game is stuck in the development limbo known as Vaporware. Few to no details have been released about about its gameplay, plot, or release date since its announcement many years ago. It may or may not be in active development, but neither has it been cancelled officially.




Deep Down is a single-player game with the option to have up to four players in co-op multiplayer, akin to that of Dark Souls, with random players dropping into the player's world to help them defeat monsters and find artifacts.

The player perspective for Deep Down begins in New York City in the year 2094. By touching magical artifacts, players are teleported into the distant past to explore dungeons and avoid or battle monsters and seek treasure. Each of these dungeons are randomly generated for each player. As well as this, the artifacts you touch correspond to an emotion, including anger, rage, hate, envy, lust and wrath.

Source: Wikipedia, "Deep Down (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Heroes & Generals
Heroes and Generals
boardgame.description:
Heroes & Generals is a combined first-person shooter and strategy video game in a World War II setting. It is being developed by independent studio Reto-Moto, which is founded by some of the original founders of IO Interactive and the Hitman series, and will be published by Square Enix.

The developers call it a "mass participation game" in contrast to a traditional massively multiplayer online games, where the actions in the FPS-part of the game reflects into the strategy-part. The player can use weapons from Germany, the United States, and the Soviet Union.

Gameplay
The player starts with a soldier from each faction (United States, Soviet Union, Germany) and can buy additional soldiers with in-game credits. These soldiers are equipped with a default rifle and can play the Encounter game mode immediately. When entering a battle, the player is presented with an interactive map, showing terrain and which team controls which control points. In the Skirmish and Encounter game modes, the player must click on the spawn point of their team (or called faction) and can choose whether to spawn on foot or in a vehicle. In the Assault game mode, the same rules apply, except players can also spawn on control points captured by their team. Teams will always consist of soldiers from the same nation, unlike some World War II games that have teams of mixed nationalities. The game includes World War II era tanks, planes, and land vehicles. Infantry units are also a vital game play aspect. Tactical decisions made by officers in grand campaigns affect in-game support, reinforcements, and logistics. Players will encounter a variety of terrain, from fields and countryside to large cities. The game features three game modes for the FPS-part of the game: Assault, Skirmish and Encounter.

Source: Wikipedia, "Heroes & Generals", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: ZigZag
Zigzag Pocket
boardgame.description:
Some cute little people have invaded the land, and when they get together in groups of four they trigger strange symptoms in humans. Apparently, this game is so much fun that you may lose control of your faculties, causing others to chant "Zig! Zag!"

ZigZag is a partnership game (with variants for two and three players) that is played with a deck of 93 cards. Of those cards, 64 show the aforementioned cute little people, and each one of these cards has three characteristics: a person representing one of the four elements, a landscape, and an accessory (sunglasses, a suitcase, etc.)

The goal of the game is to get sets of four cards with a single characteristic (Zig) or two characteristics (Zag) in common. To finish a round, it is necessary to complete a zig, a zag, a double zig, or a zig and a zag. Each combination is allowed only once, and the first partnership to complete all four wins. When a player has completed a set, he must give a pre-arranged signal to his partner, who must then announce what type of set has been completed out loud. If a signal is mistaken, both partners must discard their cards, draw new hands, and play on.

Everyone plays at the same time, exchanging cards with those cards in the center of the table. Beware as the opposing team will do all they can to prevent you from achieving your goal, including using some of the 17 special cards that do things like stop you from collecting a set with a certain characteristic or force an exchange of hands.

In the two- to three-player variant of ZigZag, each player receives one of twelve constraint cards, which limits the types of sets they can collect.

boardgame.name: Back to the Future: The Game
boardgame.description:
From Wikipedia:
Back to the Future: The Game is an episodic point-and-click adventure role-playing video game based on the Back to the Future film franchise. The game is split up into five episodes. Telltale published the series as retail products for the PlayStation 3 and Nintendo Wii consoles for North America. Deep Silver published the retail Nintendo Wii and PlayStation 3 versions for Europe on May 4, 2012.

Back to the Future: The Game is a point-and-click adventure role-playing video game, played from a third-person perspective. The player controls Marty to explore the 3D environments using either the keyboard, mouse or game controller to move around. The player can have Marty examine objects, talk to non-player characters (initiating dialog through conversation trees), and perform specific actions in order to solve puzzles and progress the game. Some items can be picked up and stored in Marty's inventory, and then can be used later to interact with other characters or objects. The game provides a list of current goals for the player to complete to advance the game. The player can access a hint system, revealing one clue at a time from a number of cryptic clues for how to solve a specific puzzle.

Source: Wikipedia, "Back to the Future: The Game," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Content Descriptors:
Drug and Alcohol Reference, Language, Mild Blood, Mild Violence, Sexual Themes

Rating Summery:
This is an adventure game based on the Back to the Future movie franchise. Players assume the role of Marty McFly, a teenager who must travel through time to rescue his friend and restore a dystopian version of his hometown. A variety of sequences contain brief instances of violence (e.g., men threatening each other with pistols; a character getting punched in the face; a man being slapped while tied to a chair). One scene depicts a small puddle of blood, though no related violence is shown. Some sequences contain dialogue that is sexual in nature (e.g., “ehaviors that excite your privates should be kept in private,” “They weren't. . . hookers?” and “[L]ook! Girlie mags!”/Boobies?”). In one scene, a magazine stack is identified as “porn.” During the course of the game, the dialogue references alcohol (e.g., “Booze,” “Beer, rum, whiskey, wine coolers, you name it, I drank it,” “. . . drunken bums,” and “Under the influence of alcohol, my mom made a pass at me.”). In one scene, a police officer asks if a character is “on the pot.” The words “sh*t,” “b*tch,” and “a*s” can be heard in dialogue.

Source: ESRB ratings, "ESRB Ratings: Back to the Future: The Game,"

boardgame.name: Sword of Legendia
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




Sword of Legendia was revealed with traiers showing various interviews with developers, one of which was with Makoto Yoshizumi. He was discussing the controller, and he then showed a single piece of artwork. Little was said on the game after this, however, the game remained listed on Namco's Japanese website in their Wii games section.

After the long quiet period, Tsutomu Gouda commented on the game in a 2008 interview regarding the then-upcoming Tales of Vesperia. He confirmed that he was in charge of the game, the game was still in development, that the game would likely undergo a title change before release , as it was not meant to be associated with the Tales series.

On May 19, 2009 in an interview Kentarou Kawashima satated that details of Legendia were unable to be disclosed. In a French interview with Makoto Yoshizumi, it was revealed that Sword of Legendia had been cancelled for several years.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sword of Legendia", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Been There, Done That
boardgame.description:
From one of the creators of Trivial Pursuit.
Object: move along the coloured rope convincing your opponents that you have BEEN THERE AND DONE THAT. To win players must move in the inner drum and convincing opponents that you have truly BEEN THERE AND DONE THAT.

Roll the die, move your pawn the required number of spaces along your colour of rope (picture on game board), Opponent asks a question from the cards. If you answer no, the next player goes. After a vote, if the vote is no, the next player goes, if yes roll again and continue until a no vote or no response.

This easy-to-play game is a great ice breaker for groups of new friends and a must have at every family game night. With over 850 scenarios, including suggestions for large groups and other fun variations, no game is ever the same!"

A roll of the dice decides whether you select a "been there" or "done that" card and then everyone votes "yes" or "no" to the question. Players try to guess how many players have "been there" or "done that" to earn points.

boardgame.name: TagOn
boardgame.description:
ABOUT THE GAME

TagOn® is a Bible-based, family-friendly crossword board game that provides instant fun for everyone! You've played crossword games before, but never like this! It enhances your Scriptural knowledge and promotes learning of the Bible. It provides an excellent way for families and friends to have meaningful fun while strengthening their knowledge of God's Word.

TagOn® is a game in which two to four players score points by playing and tagging Bible principal words from individual letter tiles. Words are played across or down in crossword fashion and must appear in a Bible dictionary, Bible Concordance or Bible Research Guide adopted by the players as the game dictionary. The game dictionary may be a hard copy print edition, online edition or mobile phone app. It may also be a searchable online Bible or its corresponding mobile phone app. With your game dictionary, you have set up the stage for fun!

What makes TagOn® unique and interesting? Through suspenseful action and thoughtful play, Bible books, characters, utterances, lands and genealogies of Bible characters as well as events and scenes of Bible times are dramatically revealed. What a game!

OBJECT OF THE GAME

To have fun, learn and to become the person with the most point for playing and tagging Bible words.

THE PLAY

The play of the game involves finding, playing, connecting and tagging related Bible words. Played words may have a direct connection with existing words on the game board. This game is about remembering what Bible words were said, who said them, who were related to those characters, where the words were spoken, and in which Bible book can the words be found.

Players will have opportunities to obtain extra points by playing Bible words that have a direct scriptural relationship with other words [tagging words] or/and by playing words on specific colored squares marked with Bible books, characters, utterances, lands and genealogies on the game board. The revelation of Bible characters, places, events, utterances and genealogies, combined with the tag word challenge makes playing TagOn® a fun and interesting game for the entire family.

What about playing new words by replacing existing letters on the game board? You have to see the game rules and actually play the game. Different Bible stories or events appear in every play of the game. This game is so much fun you’ll want to play until God’s Kingdom comes!

boardgame.name: Cycling Party
boardgame.description:
Cycling Party is a game for 2 to 6 players, which reflects the essential features of road cycling. Each player will select a cycling team and take responsibility for managing the movements of 5-6 riders in their team. The aim of each team will be to secure victory at the end of each stage or in the general classification.

The course is built from hexagonal tiles. Each hexagon tile is divided in turn into three spaces, with each space representing a kilometre of the race. Mountain sections, intermediate sprints and the finish line are shown using indicator tokens placed at the kilometre points agreed upon by the players at the beginning of the race.

This game comes in three versions: Junior, Senior and Master. Each version builds on the rules of previous versions. In the Junior version each rider is moved by rolling two six-sided dice. Riders in a peloton (at least five riders in the same space) may choose not to roll and instead move five spaces. A rider in the peloton may choose to roll in the hope of raising its pace or of breaking away (roll of 10-12). The difficulty of the mountain sections is represented by rolling just one dice. Each team has five water bottles that can be spent to move a rider an extra space (cost of one bottle on the flat, 2 bottles in mountains). The rider furthest across the finish line at the end of a turn is the winner.

The Senior version introduces different categories of climb and gives each team member a role (climber, sprinter, rouleur, domestique (flat or mountain), and lantern rouge). Each role has particular abilities. Each team may launch one attack by rolling four dice instead of the normal two. Falls, fast descents and falling back to join a team-mate are also represented.

The Master version makes use of software accessed through the publisher’s website to enable whole tours to be run.

boardgame.name: Eight-Year Resistance War
boardgame.description:
Eight Year Resistance War is a solitaire strategy game covering the Second Sino-Japanese War (July 7, 1937 – September 2, 1945), which was a military conflict fought primarily between the Republic of China and the Empire of Japan from 1937 to 1941. After the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, the war merged into the greater conflict of World War II as a major front of what is broadly known as the Pacific War. The Second Sino-Japanese War was the largest Asian war in the 20th century. It also made up more than 50% of the casualties in the Pacific War if the 1937–1941 period is taken into account. Although the two countries had fought intermittently since 1931, total war started in earnest in 1937 and ended only with the surrender of Japan in 1945.

In this game, you, the player, lead China’s Army (KMT Central Army) to fight against Japanese invasion. Major battles and historical events are represented by event cards which may be executed chronologically as the history (see the Historical Game option in 17.0), or randomly so as to make youself unprepared for what will happen in the next turn. You have to use your limited resources (limited number of actions, and event cards beneficial to you) to avoid Japanese capture of your Capital, Chungking. To do so, you need to gain support from Western Allies and the help from your unreliable temporary ally – Chinese Communist Party’s Red Army, which will get the final victory (China) from you if you allow them to expand and gain sufficient political support among generals, soldiers and civilians.

Errata: Page 9, [15.1] "i)..." -> "the KMTPS level <=20."

boardgame.name: Jungle Speed Safari ( )
Jungle Speed: Safari
boardgame.description:
Normally, calm reigns supreme amongst the animals of the jungle, but when the time comes to eat, the animals gather round the forest of totems and their wild instincts take over. The hungriest animals race to catch their prey first. Others become angry and shout, while the chameleon hides. When the hunter appears, there is panic as the animals race to protect themselves!

Jungle Speed Safari is a standalone game that's part of the Jungle Speed family. The core gameplay is the same, with players turning over cards from their personal stacks one by one in front of themselves and reacting when certain cards or combinations of cards appear, but Jungle Speed Safari features five wooden totems to grab instead of one, and you interact with them in different ways, with every card that's revealed possibly triggering an action. If a player reveals a hungry animal card, for example, all players must race to grab the appropriate totem to satisfy the animal. Whoever grabs that totem adds the hungry animal card to his score pile.

boardgame.name: The Battle of Midway 1942 AD
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's website:

The selections of some of the “decisive battles” have sparked conversations over the years. Vicksburg over Gettysburg? The Metarus over Zama? Syracuse?

No one has ever questioned the selection of Midway as the decisive battle of the Pacific War. All agree that this one changed everything, as the Japanese plan to “lure” the remaining US fleet to its destruction led to a strategic defeat, due to code breaking, heroism, and remarkable timing.

Now you can play out this exciting battle and see if you can do better. The Battle of Midway, June 3-6, 1942 gives you all the parts you need to gain insight into the questions facing both sides. Paul Rohrbaugh’s design blends clean simplicity with a fine level of detail (even accounting for the Japanese planes intended to be assembled and used on the captured island!). It includes an overview map-board of the area, an off-map battle board, and a variant map with Midway in detail, where, for the first time, you can pursue the actual Japanese invasion of the island and see what might have been.

Rules cover battles in the air, planes versus ships and versus land, surface to surface, submarines, seaplanes, and more, all in rules designed to be fast, combined with challenges that encourage replay.

You know the history.

Now, see if you can change it.
Part of the TPS "Decisive Battles" series

That means straightforward rules, key insights into the history behind the game, and designs aimed at one-session conclusions and high replay value."

The Battle of Midway 1942 AD includes:
• One 11” by 17” map (containing the Game Map and Battle Board)
• Two Naval/Air Unit Deployment Charts ( Japanese and US)
• 176 counters
• This set of rules
• Four six-sided (D6) dice
• Two 8.5” by 11” inserts (map and rules for the optional variant game)

Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

boardgame.name: The Flight of the Eagle
Le Vol de l'Aigle: Volume 3 Le systeme complet
boardgame.description:
Le Vol de l'Aigle III (The Flight of the Eagle III) is a wargame that recreates some of the most famous Napleonic campaigns.

The system is a double-blinded system that uses an Umpire. Players can communicate only through written messages. It uses maps of that time and a simple system to manage units. Combats are solved using a face to face system, simple but precise, with the morale as the main endpoint. Combats can also be solved using any existing operational or tactical system including miniatures.

The present volume 3 does not need the volume 1 or 2 to be played. It includes four booklets (three are over 60 pages) including all the rules of volume 1 and 2, a new edition of the tactical rules The Eagle Fights, 50 pages of data to transfer all the armies of the time between both systems, the special rules of the ten campaigns included: Bavaria and Austria 1809, France 1814 and the eight Peninsula campaigns in Spain and Portugal (around one a year between 1808 and 1814). Seven maps and 52 units sheets are included.

Cherry on the cake, an experimental recruitment module is also presented, with a strategic map, two pages of units, and rules managing every parameter involved in the Administration of War.

The game is available in French and in English.

boardgame.name: Disco Dan
boardgame.description:
From the inlay:

Can poor Dan decontaminate the atomic fuel rods in time? In this new 3D machine code game, you control Dan Dan The Atomiser man, jumping from disc to disc, trying to reduce the ever increasing radiation levels in an atomic pile.

However Up 'n' Atom 'Arry and his gang of vagrant particles are thirsting for the energy in your back pack, which makes life a bit awkward at times. The there's Ron the Rapacious Robot, not the sort to meeting a dark alley (or anywhere else for that matter)!!

User Summary

Disco Dan consists of two stages. The first stage consists of running down a tunnel to reach the reactor. The player must avoid enemies and pits.

The reactor stage is slightly reminiscent of Q*Bert in that you are jumping diagonally between various platforms with an aim to change their colour, while avoiding enemies. The difference is that each platform has a number, which is steadily increasing. Jumping on a platform reduces the number. If a disk is reduced to 0 (green) then it is safe and will no longer increase unless a neighbour explodes or Ron the Robot steps on it. If any of the discs reach the maximum number, they start to flash. If the player doesn't reach it in time it will explode and will then be shown with no number on it. Ron can be shot to remove him from the board for a time. Other roaming enemies (Atoms) can only be moved off one disc onto another.

Dan has limited energy, which is used every time he moves, fires or touches an enemy. It also steadily decreases over time, representing the power to his Life Support.

Turning all the discs green awards an extra life, but allowing all to explode results in game over.

Credits:

Coding and Design by Daren White & John Line
Tea & sympathy - Sandie & Brenda

boardgame.name: Kingdom Rush Frontiers
Kingdom Rush Frontiers HD
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Kingdom Rush Frontiers is the sequel to 2011's Kingdom Rush. In Kingdom Rush Frontiers, the player places towers in pre-determined spots on each level to defeat waves of enemies. Towers can be upgraded, and the final upgrade of each tower type gives the player a choice of two different special towers, each with its own abilities.

Although very similar to Kingdom Rush, Frontiers offers new types of enemies and 8 completely new special towers, plus the ability to use and upgrade heroes.

boardgame.description:
User Summary

'Cha-now chow-chow!'

Guide Gonch and Hollo on their quest to recover a confiscated Walkman from the titular London comprehensive school, after hours. In line with Grange Hill's anti-drug message of the mid-Eighties, one of the first encounters involved a heroin pusher. Accepting his offer of a packet of white powder results in an early death, and one of the more darker moments of videogame history. Just say no!

boardgame.name: Guerra de Mitos
Guerra de Mitos I: Norse and Japanese
Myths at War
boardgame.description:
Myths at War, first published as Guerra de Mitos, is a card game set in a fantastic world where different mythologies coexist. It is a different, dynamic game designed to be able to build different decks with very distinct and varied strategies, and each expansion increases both the number of available mythologies and the game possibilities.

This first installment of Myths at War contains 300 cards split between the Nordic, Egyptian and Japanese mythologies (GDMI+GDM3 spanish editions). Each mythology includes two pantheons (cards that define your game strategy) + cards for the gods deck (which includes characters, events and resources) + cards for the designs deck (actions, equipment and summonings).

Each player in Myths at War needs to build his own deck of at least 51 cards (1 pantheon / 20 gods / 30 designs) of his choice, and each expansion increases the diversity of characters, actions and strategies you can use in order to achieve victory but all expansions can be played on his own.

During the game, each player has to bring into play the cards his oracles offer him and play actions from the designs deck both in the influence phase (where the gods plan from their pantheon) and in the confrontation phase (where the characters who decide to go to battle fight to decrease the opponent’s power) to obtain supremacy or consign the opponent to oblivion.

boardgame.name: Finding Haven
boardgame.description:
Author's description from the text:

Finding Haven is a game about dissidents rebelling against or seeking escape from an alien force of corporate totalitarianism. And about human nature. There is that.

In Finding Haven, there’s at least three general kinds of situations you can choose to play in:

(1) Discovery: your characters all begin play as naïve citizens, believing in the worldview spread by Demosian propaganda, but you discover the horrifying truth in the first session or two. You might be taking winners of the Culling to meet a Starliner around Europa station, or supplies to and from Io. Something goes wrong, and someone winds up seeing something they shouldn't. DE finds out something is off, and a patrol ship goes to investigate.

(2) Escape and Pursuit: your characters know the awful truth: the Demosians do send the winners of the Culling off to Jupiter, but there are no starliners taking them to Wonderland: they are used as incubation chambers for Demosian eggs. When the larvae hatch, they slowly eat their way out of the paralyzed hosts. Those culled on the other hand are used as fresh meat for adult Demosians, and occasionally recycled as cheap meat for human fast food restaurants a la soylent green. You’ve heard of something called Haven on pirate broadcasts, a place safe from the aliens, and you’ve stolen or hijacked a ship and are trying to find it. The Demosian Enforcers of course are trying to find you.

(3) Rebellion: In an Earth-based game, the PCs can be fighting a rebel war, probably mostly covert, against the Demosians. Goals will include both striking against Demosian targets and trying to get their message out to the general population.

User comment
Finding Haven was runner-up in the English part of Game Chef 2013: Icons.

boardgame.name: Beach Buggy Simulator
boardgame.description:
From the inlay:

You've just bought yourself a shiny new beach buggy and entered the Dune Trials to show everyone how excellent it is. Burn across the sand hills, jump over the rocks and fire, and if you have to, shoot out the helicopters. Beat the clock and qualify for the next, harder, round.

User Summary

In Beach Buggy Simulator, the player views an undulating course from side-on. The Buggy drives from left to right. The course is strewn with boulders and fires. The player must jump this obstacles otherwise the Buggy will explode. Also hindering progress are helicopters which can be shot at or avoided.

A bar at the bottom left shows progress through the level, which must be completed before the timer runs out. The player does not have limited lives, but the obstacles slow down progress and cost the player fuel. If the fuel runs out, the speed of the Buggy is reduced to a crawl. Fuel can be replenished by driving over fuel dumps scattered through the level.

boardgame.name: Frakkin' Epic
boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

Many geeks known of Beau M. K. Prichard for his behind-the-scenes involvement in Zombie Orpheus Entertainment series like JourneyQuest and Rude Mechanical. He's also a producer on the super nerdy web series Glitch. On the way back from the Fandemonium con in Idaho, Jesse Lee Keeter (star of Glitch and JourneyQuest) asked if there was a way to play D&D in the backseat. Beau came up with what eventually developed into Frakkin' Epic, the simple, fast-paced, perfect-for-roadtrips, RPG system. This is a game that rewards creativity, encourages shenanigans, and makes table top gaming, fast, accessible, and fun for practically everyone.

boardgame.name: Them's Fightin' Words!
boardgame.description:
You take the role of an irritable cowboy, slinging insults from a deck of cards in front of you in order to be the last man standing.

The game uses a starting word and a deck of second and final words distributed amongst all players. Everyone takes it in turns to say the first word, then all the words on the cards in the middle pile, then the top card from their hand (which is added to the pile) followed by the final word. If you cannot remember the entire phrase you take all the cards in the middle pile as one "hit". When you take your third "hit" you are out of the game.

Hats are not required but cowboy voices are mandatory.

boardgame.name: Packet Row
Packet Row: New York, 1842
boardgame.description:
New York, 1842: The docks along South Street bustle with activity. Packet ships are constantly arriving and departing. There are so many packet ships waiting along the docks that the area has become known as the "Packet Row".

In the game Packet Row, each player represents a trading company that's trying to make as much profit as possible on the trans-Atlantic trade. boardgame.name: 5150: Fighter Command
boardgame.description:
In 5150 - Fighter Command you can command a flight of combat spacecraft fighters. You're the eyes and ears of the fleet and lives depend on you doing your job. Your job is simple: sweep the stars of the enemy. For you it's not who the enemies are but where they are. Your missions will range from patrolling in front of the fleet, to attacking the enemy when you find them, to defending the fleet. You'll be fighting a variety of Races and Factions who want nothing more than to take you out. In 5150 - Fighter Command you'll find:

Rules for squadron level fighter and spaceship combat. Dynamic mission, combat and dogfighting rules let you play head-to-head, co-op and solo. Take the helm as any of the primary Factions and Races in the 5150 Universe. Pre-generated scenarios and missions for quick-start battles. Complete campaign rules let you run your Fighter pilot or Ship's captain through an entire story line.

5150 - Fighter Command can be played solo, same side with everyone against the game, and of course head-to-head against your friends. Playable with any ship models, in any scale, this easy to learn yet tough to master game is perfect for the casual or battle hardened space gamer.

boardgame.name: NE
the niversal NPC emulator
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

The role of a game master ("GM") running a tabletop roleplaying game can be a tough one. Not only do they have to maintain a handle on the stage they are setting, but they also have to keep things interesting. A lot of times a GM will look towards a pre-made adventure - many of which require players to do A then B then C to get D, etc. - to save some time in the game preparation. Just as many times, players will start at A then send their characters to X, destroy C, and then run away from D to get to M. All the GM's planning in the world cannot account for every action the players want their characters to take.

Perhaps the worst situation in which a GM can find himself results when a player character ("PC") is trying to have an unforseen conversation with a non-player character ("NPC"). For example, the Mayor that Dooley wants to meet. The GM could just ignore the player's request and say that the Mayor says nothing interesting. Another GM could use the Mayor to get the PC's back on track with the prepared adventure. A GM could take a break to flesh out the area the PC's want to explore.

This supplement attempts to help a GM create interesting NPC's on the fly so that if the third option is taken, the task is simpler and the results fun. Instead of just a stereotypical Mayor (whatever that may be), with a few die rolls a Mayor can be created with a history, motivations, and even a reason to speak with the PC's. The best part is that this supplement is universal. It was designed to work for every genre from fantasy to horror, space opera to post-apocalypse adventure.

boardgame.name: Hexa Sea
boardgame.description:
Welcome to the Hexa Sea, General. This land is vital to our Nation. We must hold it at any cost, and remove the enemy's presence. Set a hold in the land of the Hexa Sea, bring forth our Army, and strike deep at the enemy headquarters. Win for us.

Hexa Sea is an abstract, terrain control wargame played on a modular map that changes every new game. You set hold on the map with your Headquarters, build new units and fight your opponent off the map.

The board is comprised of sea tiles and land pieces called Hexas. These Hexas are arranged over the board forming islands with land tiles. Controlling different numbers of Hexas allow the player to build different units, that interact between themselves in different ways. The goal of the game is to capture the Soldier controlling your opponent's Headquarters.

3rd Best Overall Game, 3rd Best Art/Graphic Design, 2nd Best New Mechanic and 2nd Best Wargame at the 2013 Two-Player PnP Game Design Contest

boardgame.name: Mystres?
Mysteries?
boardgame.description:
Mysteries? is a game of riddle and deduction in which one player has to come up with subtle clues to make others guess a word.

First, the "Master of Mysteries" discreetly draws a card and a category tile to know which word they must make the other players guess. (The twelve categories are book, film/TV, music/song, famous person, generic person, shape/color, number, matter, item, place, animal, and verb.) They then set down a square of nine (3x3) category tiles on the table (including the one she just drew). In turns, other players choose a category. If it matches the word to be guessed, the "Master of Mysteries" says so and sets the tile aside; if not, they must either give a clue matching this category, then flip the tile (which cannot be chosen again), or discard the tile and place it back in the bag. At the end of each turn, the active player can make one guess, and if their answer is right, both the guesser and the Master of Mysteries scores as many points as the number of non-discarded tiles chosen during that round.

After a clue has been given or a tile discarded, any player can interrupt the game by saying they know the answer. Any other players can then do the same. Then, in clockwise order, each of them gives one answer, and either wins this round or is eliminated until next round.

After a certain number of rounds (depending on the number of players), the player with the most points wins.
boardgame.boardgamefamily: Mechanism: Give a Clue / Get a Clue

boardgame.name: Roolipelaaja (Issue 3 - Aug 2006)
boardgame.description:
user summary

This is a special issue of Roolipelaaja, as this was also the program booklet of Ropecon 2006 convention and was given for free at the 'con. The issue is "doublesided", meaning that half of the issue is printed upside down, so if starting to read from the issue cover one sees the regular articles of Roolipelaaja, but if starting from the backcover, it is actually the program booklet of Ropecon.

Index of issue #3:
- Tervehdys ('Greetings'): Editiorial.
- Ajankohtaista ('Current'): Current news from rpg front around the world.
- Knutpunkt 2006: Report from rpg convention Knutpunkt 2006 Stockholm Sweden.
- Rikos kannattaa ('Crime does pay'): Report from a crime larp held 9.-11.6.2006 in Helsinki, Finland.
- Kotimaisen roolipelijulkaisemisen uusi aalto ('New wave of Finnish rpg publishing'): New Finnish rpg publications.
- Con-innostuksen lähteillä ('At the source of con-enthusiastic'): column.
- Kädettömät sankarit ('Useless heroes'): Showcasing and review of RuneQuest fourth edition.
- Kulta-ajan raunioilla, tähtien äärellä ('At the ruins of golden age, near the stars'): Showcasing and review of science fiction rpg Heimot published by Ironspine.
- Avaruuden avuttomat antisankarit ('Helpless antiheroes of the space'): Showcasing and review of Star Wreck Roleplaying Game.
- Vetävää fantasiaa simulaatioiden ystäville ('interesting fantasy for the friends of simulations'): Showcasing and review of rpg Parabellum.

Articles from Ropecon side of the issue:
- Salaliittoteorioiden sekatyöläinen ('Labourer of conspiracy theories'): An article about rpg designer Kenneth Hite.
- Tie auki taivasta myöten ('Road is free up to the heavens'): An article about Swedish Vi åker jeep rpg-collevtive actives Olle Jonsson and Tobias Wrigstad.
- Vapaamuotoista roolipelaamista ('Freeform roleplaying'): An article about freeform roleplaying.
- Kaaosta ja yhteistyötä ('Chaos and co-operation'): An article about boardgame designer Bruno Faidutti.

boardgame.name: A Game of Toll Gate
boardgame.description:
"A Game of Toll Gate" is a variation (such as India - An Oriental Game) of the Parcheesi game.
The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the "home" section. Movement is controlled by dice. All players move around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to their player's corner and must start their journey over. The winner is the first player to move all pawns "home".
Components: 4 purple, 4 green, 4 yellow, and 4 red playing pieces; 4 die and 2 shakers made of wood.

boardgame.name: Dungeon Twister: Das Kartenspiel
Dungeon Twister: Le Jeu de Cartes
Dungeon Twister: The Card Game
boardgame.description:
Dungeon Twister: The Card Game is a two-player-only take on Dungeon Twister with the entire game converted into cards. As in the original game, players in Dungeon Twister: The Card Game build a team from the characters and objects available to them, then head into the maze to try to navigate the hazards by using their action points each turn to move, rotate rooms, collect items, and combat opponents, making their way to the opposite side of the maze while avoiding – or taking out – the opponent's characters along the way.

Before starting the game, players choose a scenario card that details the number of rooms in the maze and the number of characters and objects each player uses. With the scenario cards, players can learn the game progressively, starting with the easiest scenario – which uses 2x2 rooms and starts each player with two characters and two objects – and moving into more difficult scenarios from there.

boardgame.name: Amalgam
Glastonbury
boardgame.description:
In Glastonbury, the players are witches and wizards who shop for ingredients for their magic potions. Your token moves around the perimeter of an array of ingredient cards, and you pick one from the row or column where you stop. The number on the card you pick dictates how many spaces you move on your next turn.

To score points, you need to collect sets of four matching ingredients; if you have only one of a particular ingredient, you'll score penalty points instead. The scoring rules can be made more complicated if the players desire, but for most the basic rules are satisfying. A touch of memory is involved since you can see only the most recently chosen ingredient on your stack of cards.

Glastonbury is a new edition of the 2001 release Kupferkessel Co. with slight changes to the game. Now the game can be played by up to four players instead of being strictly a two-player game. The game includes additional ingredient cards and new spell cards that allow special actions.

listing.notes:
Spieleranzahl: 2 bis 4 Spieldauer: 30 Minuten Altersempfehlung: 8+
GLASTONBURY Willkommen in Glastonbury, der magischen Stadt. In der High Street finden Sie alles, was Sie an wirkungsvollen Zutaten fr Ihre mchtigen Zaubertrnke brauchen. Abwechselnd sammeln die Spieler Zutatenkarten fr ihre Zaubertrnke ein und legen sie auf ihre Ablagestapel, die Zauberkessel. Jeder Spieler versucht dabei mglichst viele der Karten mit der jeweils gleichen Zutat einzusammeln. Er sieht jedoch immer nur die oberste Zutatenkarte in seinem Kessel. Daher muss er sich merken, welche Zutaten er bereits gesammelt hat. Sonst kann es bei Spielende unangenehme berraschungen geben, denn Zutatenkarten, die nur einmal im Kessel liegen, zhlen Minuspunkte. Bei Spielende werden die gesammelten Zutaten gewertet und es gewinnt der Spieler mit den meisten Punkten.
Die Kleinstadt Glastonbury im Sdwesten Endlands ist ein magischer Ort mit esoterischem Flair. Die Stadt erhebt den Anspruch, das sagenhafte Avalon zu sein. Hier soll am Fue des Glastonbury Tor (siehe Cover) einst der Heilige Gral versteckt worden sein. An der Stelle der Ruine einer alten Abtei sollen angeblich 1190 die sterblichen berreste von Knig Artus entdeckt worden sein. Heute ist die Stadt ein esoterisches und spirituelles Zentrum in England. Bei Freunden der Rockmusik ist sie auch durch das Glastonbury-Festival bekannt.
Im Jahre 2001 erschien das 2-Personen-Spiel KUPFERKESSEL CO. vom Autor Gnter Burkhardt bei Goldsieber. Das Spiel wurde von der Jury Spiel des Jahres 2002 auf die Auswahlliste der besten Spiele des Jahres gewhlt. Ebenfalls in 2002 wurde KUPFERKESSEL CO. mit dem sterreichischen Spiele-Preis "Spiele-Hit fr 2" ausgezeichnet. Bei der Wahl zum Kartenspiel des Jahres der Zeitschrift FAIRPLAY erreichte das Spiel einen 8. Platz. Trotzdem verschwand das Spiel nach einiger Zeit wieder aus den Regalen der Hndler und war nur noch vereinzelt zu hohen Preisen im Internet zu bekommen.
Anfang 2013 bin ich per Zufall auf der amerikanischen Spiele-Datenbank boardgamegeek.com auf das Spiel gestoen. Dort war auch zu lesen, dass der Autor mittlerweile eine Erweiterung fr 3 Spieler vorgesehen hatte. Nach der Kontaktaufnahme mit Gnter Burkhardt stellte sich heraus, dass er das Spiel weiterentwickelt hatte, so dass es jetzt sogar fr bis zu vier Spieler geeignet war.
Hinzugekommen sind die Zauberkarten, die fr zustzliche Spannung sorgen. Auerdem gibt es jetzt fr jeden Spieler eine Kupferkessel-Karte.
Fr die auslndischen Vertriebspartner war ein neuer Titel ntig. Die Idee zu GLASTONBURY als Titel stammt vom Autor persnlich, der diese mystische Stadt im Jahre 2012 auf einer Reise kennengelernt hat.
Mit Spielregeln in folgenden Sprachen: DE, EN, FR, ES

Welcome to Glastonbury, the Wizard's Village! Here you can get all the ingredients you need to make a powerful magic pill.

boardgame.name: Raumstation Theseus
Tezeusz: Mroczna Orbita
Theseus: La Station abandonne
Theseus: The Dark Orbit
boardgame.description:
Theseus: The Dark Orbit puts players in the heart of a conflict between five factions trapped on a space station in deep space. Only one can survive...


Command the marine forces! Use deadly weaponry, setting traps and mines in corridors to defend the human race.



Command the alien race! Use secret passages and ventilation ducts to launch surprise attacks and grow small aliens to take control of the station.



Command the scientists! Use computers and technological devices to gather data and record information about other inhabitants of the station.



Command the Greys race! Use their mind powers to control the enemy and use them for your own purposes.



The fifth faction? It's a mystery. It's precisely why you made the trek to Theseus, and it's precisely why you will die...


In Theseus: The Dark Orbit, players move their pawns around the space station and activate the abilities of different rooms. Every move you take changes the movement possibilities of your opponent. On your turn, you need to think about which room you want to reach and (in addition) how to mess your opponent's movement, which leads to great choices and meaningful decisions.

Rooms abilities change during the game as players install trait cards that give rooms new abilities and skills. Players create Theseus during gameplay by placing traps, smart guns, secret passages and many other features. In every game Theseus looks different; in every game it's deadly for you in a new way...

Rules for team play allow players to engage in incredibly emotional 2-vs-2 battles. With perfectly balanced factions, players will be able to fight engaging and deadly battles as a teams. Each faction has a unique deck of cards, and before the game starts, you discard ten cards from the deck. In basic mode you discard at random, while in tournament (master) mode you choose cards and build your deck. With five factions and 110 cards, the game can provide years of unique experiences.

boardgame.name: Matapan
boardgame.description:
Matapan is a card game simulating the battle of Cape Matapan, which took place in March 1941 between Italian Regia Marina and English Royal Navy.
Matapan is a turn-based game for two players. It's played over a grid of 8x8 cards. Alternatingly, each player turns over one of his and one of his opponent's cards. When both cards show ships, a battle takes place.
The object of the game is to score more points than your opponent, by sinking his ships.

boardgame.name: Condottieri Conflicts
boardgame.description:
Since the time before the plague swept Europe to the final days of the Napoleonic Campaign, bands of soldiers were contracted to protect the interests of the small city states of Europe.These soldiers for hire came to be known as Condottieri. But these soldiers were not just Italian arms for hire, soldiers flooded into the northern Italian city states from all over Europe. German Landsknechte fought alongside Welsh Longbows; Moorish Cavalry rode alongside Albanian Stratioti; Swiss Reisläufer and Scottish Highlander Kerns shared in their profits; knights of many noble backgrounds and nationalities toured alongside each other for wealth and glory. Most Famously “Sir” John Hawkwood, Albertico da Barbiano, Cesare Borgia and Cosimo de’ Medici all fought as condottiere in various Italian Wars. Conflicts ranged from skirmishes to large scale battles of thousands of heavily armored soldiers fighting to fulfill their contracted duties. This was the dawn of the modern era, the birth of contractual agreement released men from serfdom, and the rise of the first full time professional armies along with their experienced leaders since the fall of Rome.

Condottieri Conflicts is a game which lets players explore the nature of uneasy alliances, allows players to wage battle and negotiate victory conditions in search of riches, glory, and honor. Challenge your friends and family to conflict at its rawest and most cutthroat level. Command your army, form alliances, and backstab your rivals to vanquish the strongest enemies and wage war unlike any other war game you have played before.

This is a game that plays just as well with 2 players as it does with 8. You recieve fully customizable armies ready for medieval warfare, and you also receive Sterritt Strategy’s unique terrain system. Great for any gamer who thinks chess could use more realism, Diplomacy© and Risk© lack tactical skill, or might not have the time or space for classic War Games with miniatures. This is for gamers who want a strategic platform that they can tailor to their an hour of leisure time, the rainy afternoon or their multiple weekend long campaigns.

Game was added to the 2nd issue of "Taktyka and Strategia" magazine. It uses mechanic titled "B35", used for battles fought in 1943-1945 at the western front. Full rules were published years after in the game "Bitwy Drugiej Wojny wiatowej".

boardgame.name: Lenino
boardgame.description:
This game simulates tactical battle that took place between October 12 and October 13, 1943, north of the village of Lenino in Byelorussia. Polish and soviet forces were trying to break german defense on the river Miereya. Because of the lack of artillery support and bad commands of the soviet HQ, polish 1st Infantry Division lost above suffered 25% casualties, while soviert forces were too weak to succesfully use polish victory.
The battle is prominent in Polish military history, as it was one of the first major engagements of Polish Armed Forces in the East.
Game was published in the 1st issue of the "Taktyka and Strategia" magazine. It uses rules of the B35 system, meant for all battles fought between 1943-1945. Gathered together, whole rules of this systerm were published in the game "Bitwy II Wojny wiatowej".

boardgame.name: Heroes of Hellas 2: Olympia
boardgame.description:
User Summary

In the second sequel of this amazing match 3 puzzle game your primary objective is to increase the population of your city, develop its economy and infrastructure with the ultimate purpose of defeating Briarey, an evil entity, recovering the Rod of Discord and restoring peace.

Developer Summary

A mix of addictive match-three gameplay and city building fun, Heroes of Hellas 2 challenges you to drag your mouse across chains of identical items to remove obstacles, activate bonus items and collect valuable objects.

Build a city from the ashes of a fallen civilization and rule your people with wisdom and justice in Heroes of Hellas 2: Olympia. A mix of addictive match-three gameplay and city building fun, Heroes of Hellas 2 challenges you to drag your mouse across chains of identical items to remove obstacles, activate bonus items and collect valuable objects.

Dazzling visual effects will ignite your screen as you unleash powerful lightning strikes and call upon the gods to cast spells. Between levels, you can play one of eight captivating mini-games and spend the gold you earn on new buildings and upgrades for your city. Keep the people happy and they'll sing your praises in the streets; leave them to starve and you'll incur the wrath of the gods.

Once you complete the Campaign Mode, you can play again to earn all of the trophies, try to beat the game on a higher difficulty setting or play one of the additional modes for an extended experience. Packed with dozens of hours of game time, Heroes of Hellas 2 is as epic as the classic stories that inspired it!

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Les Btisseurs: Moyen-ge
Die Baumeister: Mittelalter
Budowniczowie: redniowiecze
The Builders: Middle Ages
Los Constructores: Edad Media
I Costruttori del Medioevo
ptmesterek: Kzpkor
boardgame.description:
In The Builders: Middle Ages, the cards represent buildings or workers. Players score points (and gain money) by completing the construction of buildings, while placing a worker on a construction site costs money. Each building has four characteristics (carpentry, masonry, architecture, tilery) rated between 0 and 5, and the workers have the same characteristics valued in the same range. To complete a construction, the player must add enough workers to cover the four characteristics of the building.

Each player starts the game with 10 ecu and an apprentice. Five workers and five buildings are placed face-up on the table, with the others set aside in separate decks. On a turn, you can take three free actions, then pay 5 ecu for each additional action. The possible actions are:


Open a site - Take one of the five buildings, place it front of you, then draw a replacement from the deck.
Recruit a worker - Take one of the five workers, place it front of you, then draw a replacement from the deck.
Assign a worker to a building - Pay the cost of the worker (as he won't work for free!), then place him on a building; when the building's needs are met, you earn the points and coins indicated, then flip the building over. The workers return to your pool of available labor.
Get money - Forgo one, two or three actions to earn 1, 3 or 6 ecu.


Some completed buildings join your labor pool as they can be used to complete other buildings. As soon as a player reaches 17 points, players finish the round so that everyone has the same number of turns, then you tally points, with each completed card having a point value and each 10 ecu being worth 1 point. Whoever has the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Pantheon Kingdoms Demo
boardgame.description:
This is a free Print and Play Demo of a continuing project. This Demo is complete and playable.

Theme
The theme of the game revolves around Deities, and their involvement in the epic conflict amongst civilizations over the course of centuries. The theme of the provided Demo Map is fantastical, but any map or setting that players wish to design may be played. A generic-universal rules system invites you to create or recreate the Theme as your game group likes, be it historical, mythological, or fantastical, or any mix thereof.

Gameplay
Turn-based strategy on region-based map. Actions use a point allocation system and are resolved by dice rolls using d4/d6/d8/d10/d12/d20-type dice.

Players take the roles of Deities who can use Powers to influence gameplay while also directing their Follower Units and more powerful Summoned Units on the World Map in a variety of possible actions such as battling, converting or assassinating enemy Units. Each player's Units have unique stats which are derived from those of their Deity and which control what type of dice to roll in each situation.

This Demo version includes 5 pre-designed Deities for playtesting; the full game permits players to design Deities of any kind, again, historical, mythological or fantastical, or any mix thereof.

Goal
To have more friendly Follower Units on the board at the end of the game than any other player. This goal can be pursued through a variety of means, primarily those of warfare and subterfuge (reducing enemy Followers), expansion and development (increasing friendly Followers) or politics and conversion (affecting the allegiance of Followers.

boardgame.name: Where Art Thou Romeo?
Where Art Thou Romeo? Deluxe Edition
boardgame.description:
Where Art Thou Romeo? is a nanogame in which 3-5 players take turns taking on the role of Juliet, who is attempting to find Romeo amongst the others players. Each card, other than Juliet, has two different roles from which to choose. Players holding these cards choose one of the two roles, which will subsequently make them want to convince the Juliet player that they either are or are not Romeo or perhaps point out who they think Romeo might be.

The game lasts 3-5 rounds depending upon the number of players with each player taking on the role of Juliet once. The player with the most influence points at the end of the game wins.

boardgame.name: Neon Zone
boardgame.description:
Enter the Neon Zone - a game where simple shapes become challenging puzzles.

Neon Zone is a physics-based brain teaser in which walls become floors as you turn your phone. The objective is simple: Slide the block to absorb all energy spheres in order to advance to the next level. Move the block by rotating the phone and tap to jump to the floors above while you avoid falling off the level.
Neon Zone can be as casual or as challenging as you want. Challenge yourself or your peers to reach a perfect score or just play at your own leisure.

Neon Zone is designed to be a pick-up-and-play experience and can be enjoyed whether you have thirty seconds or an hour to spare.

Key Features

- Pick up and play
- 72 unique levels
- Physics-based puzzles
- Minimalistic gameplay
- Extra rewards for replay value

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Rescue Roby
boardgame.description:
User Summary

In Rescue Roby, you play the role of Roby, a robot who was rejected from the factory line and sent to the scrap metal pile. He escaped, and now his goal is to find his way into the shipping crate to escape the factory.

On each level, Roby is sitting atop a stack of crates, and your goal is to destroy the crates in such a way as to get him into the shipping crate. Sometimes you will need to pop a crate to have him drop; other times you will need to pop crates to create an incline. Use logic and timing to get Roby out of the factory, and don't forget to collect your three stars along the way!

boardgame.name: Upon a Fable: Player Order Cards
boardgame.description:
These oversized player order cards feature Ruth Sanderson's gorgeous artwork from Upon a Fable and are available only for Kickstarter backers and as promotional giveaways. Their use in the game is optional, but gives players an elegant and random way to determine player order at the beginning of each game.

Before the Upon a Fable game starts, each player draws one card from this deck. The player who draws card #1 is the starting player and selects the first seat at the playing table. Players then take seats to the left of the starting player in ascending order of their player card number. Once the seating order has been arranged for the game, the player order cards are set aside and are no longer used until the next game.

boardgame.name: Where's my Cupcake?
boardgame.description: A children's game involving collecting matching cupcakes for children aged 3-7. At the start of the game 10 cupcake cards are placed on the table. Gameplay is very simple and involves drawing a cupcake from a pile, and checking for a match with cupcakes on the table or at the top of anyone's cupcake pile. If it matches a cupcake on the table you may take the pair, if it matches the cake on the top of your pile you keep it, if it matches a cake on another players pile you must give it to them, otherwise it is added to the table. The games teaches matching, taking turns and encourages players to be polite.

boardgame.name: Circus Train (Second Edition)
boardgame.description:
Circus Train Second Edition, by designer Tom Decker, is a 1-5 player game in which you are the owner and operator of a small circus train in prohibition-era America. In this game, you and your opponents are vying to employ the best talent while putting on the most magnificent show each month. While touring the country by train, you will have the opportunity to perform while adding talent to your show through hiring the performers stranded in cities by defunct circuses. Just remember to keep an eye on your wages, because your talent definitely will.

Through clever card hand management, you control the movement of your train around the American northeast, making strategic business decisions about talent, performances and payroll in this fast-paced strategy game. Each turn represents one week of real time, and after six months, the circus season closes for the year and the game ends with one player declared as having The Greatest Show on Earth.

Inspired by Sara Gruen’s novel, Water for Elephants, Circus Train Second Edition includes thematic elements such as improving your show’s reputation by picking up alcohol for your talent and staff (legally, in Canada), the high costs of supplying big cats and elephants, and the ability to “red light” (firing by throwing off the train) disgruntled talent or talent that has simply become too expensive to maintain. These elements are blended into the game’s mechanics, keeping it all simple while adding layers of depth and strategy.

What's New in 2nd Edition:

This new edition combines the first edition with its first expansion. Along with a graphic face-lift, it adds more players (3 more), thereby changing the experience for a gamer and how they play Circus Train 2nd Edition. It also adds new, never-before-seen Event cards into the mix.

boardgame.name: For the Crown (Second Edition)
boardgame.description:
Civil war has broken out between two royal brothers over the succession of the kingdom, and the people of a once-peaceful nation must choose sides and rush to war. Even when the sun goes down, the war for the crown does not cease. While the battle rages on during the day, both princes and their armies still hope to catch the other unawares under the blanket of darkness. Neither side is safe even then, however, and so both princes are well prepared - they've gone through lengths to recruit special units to surprise their enemy, including a Phantom to cloak itself and hopefully use the darkness to its advantage in order to capture the rival King and Heirs.

In For the Crown, you must gather key resources, train an army from scratch, and capture the rival King and Heirs to prove your claim to the throne!

In this game that combines the highly popular "deck-building" mechanic with the most engrossing variations of Chess, do you have what it takes to wisely divide your attention between preparations and military maneuvering? To outpace your opponent’s development while eluding capture? Strategize your position and seize glory in For the Crown!
